justification: The Methods section states: “Implicit Association Task (IAT)… The Self-Concept IAT combines the contrast of ‘self’ versus ‘other’ with … ‘female’ versus ‘male’ … In the current study … used to assess automatic association strength,” showing the IAT operationalises implicit gender self-concept.

Under “Gender adjectives” the authors note: “We asked participants to rate how strongly they associate themselves with nine adjectives representing typically ‘feminine’ or ‘masculine’ categories … choices on the VAS … could be calculated as a measure of explicit self-association with gender.”

The paper explains: “In the interpersonal discounting task, participants chose between a generous and a selfish choice option… [This] was incorporated … as a measure of social preferences,” identifying the task as the measure of generosity.

Methods state: “In the intertemporal discounting task, participants chose between a smaller-sooner or larger-later choice option… research has previously demonstrated no gender differences in intertemporal discounting, and other studies have similarly used intertemporal discounting as a control task,” indicating this task measures delay discounting.

The authors write: “SVO task… To measure participants’ SVO, we implemented nine game items suggested in Van Lange et al.… Our aim was to use the SVO as a baseline measure of … prosociality,” linking the SVO task to the construct.

Under “Measure of embodiment” it says: “To assess the strength of the embodiment illusion, participants answered an Embodiment Questionnaire… Q1–Q5,” indicating the questionnaire measures embodiment components.
construct: Sense of embodiment (ownership / agency / avatar gender)

measured_by: Voice recording task analysed with Praat
justification: The Methods note: “The voice recordings… were processed with Praat in order to extract the mean … pitch for each repetition,” showing voice recordings served as the measure of pitch changes tied to self-representation.
